body:
Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump has been trying to distance himself from his lucrative, longtime relationship with ACN Inc., a multilevel marketing firm that has weathered regulatory investigations in three countries.
ACN last week removed virtually all mentions of Mr. Trump from its website, just after Mr. Trump was interviewed by The Wall Street Journal about his ties to ACN.
Print publications arenât so easily erased. The August 2015 issue of Success From Home magazine, which was sponsored by ACN, contains a long, gauzy feature about Mr. Trumpâs close relationship with the company, entitled âDonald Trump and ACN: A Winning Formula.â
ACNâs four founders are pictured on the cover amid palm trees at Mr. Trumpâs Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach, Fla., and an inside photo shows the quartet with the GOP presidential contender at the club âdiscussing the next phase of their relationship.â
The magazine also has a flattering article about his son, titled âEric Trump: Stepping Out of the Shadow.â ACN is a major donor to the younger Mr. Trumpâs charity golf tournament, and Eric Trump is quoted as calling ACN âan incredible company.â
The Trump campaign, Eric Trumpâs foundation and ACN didnât respond to requests for comment for this article.
Donald Trump, who has endorsed ACN since 2006, received $450,000 apiece for three of his most recent speeches for the company, in 2014 and early this year, according to documents released by his campaign.
âWhenever he speaks to the ACN audiences, Donald Trump shares pearls of wisdom gleaned from a depth of personal and business experience,â the magazine says.
The article doesnât mention that Mr. Trump was paid to appear at an ACN event, instead quoting him as saying at the event: âI do this because I love it, because I think this is a great company, and I love these ACN audiences.â
Yet in an interview with the Journal for an Aug. 14 page one article, he said, âIâm not familiar with what they do or how they go about doing that, and I make that clear in my speeches.â He said he simply did motivational speaking for the company.
ACN, which early last week said it had a âlong-standing, respected business relationship with Donald Trump,â two days later said it removed Mr. Trump from its website âwith the full support of the Trump organizationâ because of Mr. Trumpâs candidacy for president.
ACN, based in Concord, N.C., offers a âhome-based business opportunityâ for people to sell phone, wireless, TV, and energy services. Participants pay $499 to join plus other fees, and earn money in part from recruiting others who successfully sell ACN services. The company says it has about 200,000 sales representatives in 24 countries.
ACN has successfully argued againstÂ regulators in Montana, Canada and Australia who contended it was operating a pyramid scheme, in which income comes primarily from recruiting new members instead of selling products. ACN strongly denies such allegations, saying the majority of its revenue comes from âactual, billing customersâ and participants âdo not receive any compensation whatsoever for recruiting.â
Success From Home, published by a firm in Lake Dallas, Tex., is aimed at the direct-selling industry. Each month it focuses most of its content on a different company. The August edition contains snippets about ACNâs founders, articles explaining its business how-to pieces about its business, and profiles of people portrayed as successful ACN participants.
Executives at the publisher, Success Partners Holding Co., didnât respond to phone calls and emails seeking comment.

description: The August 2015 issue of Success From Home magazine, sponsored by multilevel marketing firm ACN Inc., touts its lucrative ties to Donald Trump.
title: Magazine Touts Trump’s Lucrative Ties to Multilevel Marketing Firm
